answer: That's your defense? You know what it feels like to see you with someone else? In any living room.

question: You know who I am, Penny. I don't force you to hang around.
answer: You don't force me? Fuck. So you're saying you have no interest in this, one way or the other?

question: No, I'm not saying that.
answer: Well, then, what are you saying, Chuck? Do you want me around or not? Do you even like me?

question: Of course I like you.
answer: How much?

question: What?
answer: I need to know how much you like me.

question: I don't even know what that means, "how much?" How can I rate a person in that way? That's ridiculous.
answer: You could if you felt it. If you felt it, it would be easy to rate me. You could spread your arms as wide as they would go and say, "This much, Penny."

question: Everything's complicated, Pen. Nothing's black and white like that.
answer: Do you want me around or not? If you don't, just say so, so I know. Okay?

question: I love you, Pen, in my way. Maybe not in that crazy, head-over-heels thing, but what is that, anyway? Romantic love. Isn't that just an illusion?
answer: But you just said you love me, right?

question: Over here, Strawberry-dick.
answer: Jesus, how do you know these things?

question: We even know what she actually thought it tasted like.
answer: Really? I could never find that out. What did she think?

question: It's a "need to know", my friend. So tell me, what can I do you for?
answer: I could really use an assignment, Jim. To straighten my head.

question: I got something for your head.
answer: Treesh.

question: Treesh.
answer: Leibchen. So, here's what we got. Name's Hans Colbert. Other side of the wall. We don't like him very much.

question: Bye-bye, Colbert, bye-bye.
answer: You'll work with a kraut named Keeler. He's been trailing Colbert for a month now. Knows the routine. Keeler's a drunk, so you stay sober and take charge.

question: Done and done. See you after?
answer: Prove how much you love me, baby. Kill for me. Then I'm all yours.

question: What you writing, Sig?
answer: I am keeping track of all the goings on on this street.

question: Hey, Keeler, a bird just flew by.
answer: Yah. I know how to do my job. Under the seat, please. Please, if you don't mind, a photograph. To remember.

question: Who is it?
answer: Housekeeping, Mr. Barris.

question: Good morning, Mrs. Reynolds.
answer: Another rough night, huh?

question: The human psyche is a wondrous thing.
answer: Yes, I know it is. We don't need this now, do we? Why don't we just put this away?

question: Mrs. Reynolds, may I rest my head on your bosom for a little while?
answer: Oh, that doesn't really seem like a very good idea, Mr. Barris.

question: I'm sorry. You're right. I just... I'm just without... comfort of any sort, and I... please forgive me.
answer: No harm done.

question: Thank you. Thank you. Thank you. You are a scholar and...
answer: It's fine, sir.

question: Mrs. Reynolds, what do you suppose God thinks of someone like me?
answer: God?

question: Yes, God.
answer: Well, Mr. Barris, your television shows have brought laughter and joy to millions of people. That's a very important thing, I think, in these difficult times. I would imagine God likes you very much.

question: Thank you, that's very kind. So... I should get back to...
answer: Yes, of course, sir. Don't mind me.

question: I'm really, really fucked.
answer: Get in.

question: What? Who the hell are you?
answer: No time. Get in or die. Merde. KGB. They know who you are, Monsieur Barris. It is their intention to kill you very much in East Berlin.

question: Merde! MERDE!
answer: Not to worry, my friend. I am Paul Picard, by the way. Nice to meet you. Do not worry, I am not KGB. I do not want to kill you, I want you to live a long happy life and have many dancing grandchildren to admire.

question: What the hell is that?
answer: Your ride, Monsieur Barris.

question: No fucking way.
answer: It's quite reliable and easy to operate. It will get you over the wall. Or you can stay here. In the German Democratic Republic. I will arrange for you to get a good factory job. No, you must fly, like Daedalus before you, to the freedom of the west.

question: Christ. What about you?
answer: They do not catch me, monsieur. This is my talent, to get away always. In guerre. In amour. This is my talent, and perhaps this is my curse.

question: So, did you have a nice flight?
answer: Fuck you, Jim. It was terrifying.

question: Seems the KGB knew exactly what you were up to. You were there to kill Colbert, they were there to kill you. I'm thinking we got a mole. So much hate in the world, Chuck.
answer: Am I in danger still?

question: Jesus, yes. KGB didn't go out of business since yesterday, so far as I know. You're fucked, Chuck. But our main concern should be
answer: Fuck off. What do we do?

question: Bow out. Lay low. That's what I'm gonna do. You're lucky you have another career to immerse yourself in.
answer: Thank you. Thanks. That was great.

question: Thank you. Thanks. That was great.
answer: I don't know, Chuck. It's looking bleak.

question: There's gotta be somebody in America with some talent. Ted Mack got bookings every week. Bring in the next thing. Thank you. Thank you. We'll be in touch. That was wonderful. We've been going about this all wrong. Rather than killing ourselves trying to find good acts, we just book bad ones and kill them. We kill 'em before they're through. As soon as it gets unbearable, we kill 'em. Dead.
answer: For God's sake, what are you talking about?

question: Oh, fuck me. This guy sucks. He's bringing everyone down.
answer: None of the hosts are getting it, Chuck. But we have a thought.

question: What?
answer: You host. You get it. And we believe your awkward, non-professional, mumbling persona is exactly right for the show.

question: I don't want to be on tv.
answer: Listen, we can't sit through anymore of these test shows. Do it, Chuck, or we advise the network to pull it.

question: Welcome to The Gong Show. Here's an esoteric act if there ever was one. Ephemeral. It's an ephemeral act. One that should get us our Emmy. Do we have an Emmy? We don't? Well this should get us one. Anyway, ladies and gentlemen... Big Nose! I don't know. I don't understand. Well, win a few, lose a few. We'll be back with more stuff... right after this message.
answer: You can't quit.

question: I can't quit? But I get panicky, Louise, in front of all those people.
answer: You lack confidence, that's all.

question: I lack confidence?
answer: But we'll take care of that. We'll get you some confidence powder. Leave that to us.

question: Confidence powder?
answer: Nose candy, Chuck. Blow. Snow. Flake.

question: Jamie, I can't talk anymore tonight --
answer: This is Siegfried Keeler. I need to see you.

question: Assassins do not fraternize. That Keeler was calling me could mean it was my turn to get hit.
answer: I am in town on business, Chuck. And I desire nothing more than your company for dinner. I consider you one of my closest friends.

question: Keeler.
answer: A very fancy place.

question: Only the best for my friend.
answer: The friendships one develops during wartime are remarkably strong.

question: Yes.
answer: So how is the business of television?

question: Well, it's hit and miss. I've got a new show called "Operation Entertainment" which I believe is going to kill. It's sort of a Bob Hope visiting the troops thing, but it's weekly and...
answer: Why do you do what you do, Chuck?

question: Well, I like to think that I bring joy and laughter to millions of people. I'm not saying that my shows are as good as they could be. Yet. But --
answer: Why do you kill?

question: Oh.
answer: During the second world war, I had the pleasure of killing. Yes, pleasure. I found it exhilirating. Afterwards, I could find nothing else to fill me so much with life. So I became what I am today. I wanted the exhiliration again... of death. I'll have the shrimp scampi and a green salad. Um, Just give me a steak. Rare. "Whatsoever thy hand findeth to do, do it with thy whole might. Work while it is called, for the night cometh wherein no man can work."

question: That's Carlyle!
answer: Yes.

question: It's amazing you should quote him. He's my hero.
answer: I read in a book recently that killing your first man is like making love to your first woman. Every smell, every nuance, you remember with a special allure, as if the acts had occured outside civilization, outside time. And when the allure is gone, you are condemned.

question: Condemned?
answer: I am condemned to live the rest of my life outside civilization. You will be too, my good friend.

question: When you called, I wasn't gonna come.
answer: I'm glad you did, Pen.

question: I said to myself, enough. Enough of this jerk already. Enough.
answer: I could see how you would feel that way.

question: But I've come upon something interesting through my delvings into human psychology. It's called TA, Transactual Analysis.
answer: Transactional Analysis.

question: Now see, by correcting me you're responding as "Parent" to my "Child." "Here's the proper way to say this word, Penny." But that's okay. As long as we both understand that's what you're doing. Y'know, I'm okay, you're okay. So what's wrong, Chuck? Are you okay?
answer: A guy I knew killed himself last night.

question: My God. Everyone you know kills themselves. Or tries. Who is it this time?
answer: You don't know him. A stagehand.

question: Why'd he do it?
answer: He didn't like his work anymore.

question: Is being a stagehand really bad or something?
answer: Yeah, it's pretty bad.

question: Are you serious? That's what I do for a living.
answer: Who's Patricia? What does she mean, that's what she does for a living?

question: You're dead in my book, Strawberry-dick.
answer: Strawberry dick? What's that?

question: There is no second chance. Get it? Nice meeting you, Penny. I've heard a lot about you. Oh, by the by, Byrd's dead.
answer: And... and okay... I'm only gonna give you one more chance, man. That's it. Get it?

question: Who sent you?! Who the fuck sent you?!
answer: Hey, Chuck.

question: Take it off.
answer: Huh?

question: The fucking bag. Take it off. Here he is, the Prince of Puns, the Wizard of Whoopee... The Unknown Comic!
answer: Chuckie Baby, Chuckie Baby, Chuckie Baby...

question: What? What do you want?
answer: What's the difference between toilet paper and a shower curtain?

question: I don't know.
answer: Here's the guy!

question: Get out of here.
answer: You're fucking crazy, man.

question: I'll take it! Don't hang up! Hello?
answer: Hello, is this Chuck Barris?

question: Yes.
answer: Oh, this is Tuvia Feldman. I don't know if you remember me --

question: Of course I do.
answer: I'm in town and I've been following your career and I wondered if you might want to get a drink. For old times sake.

question: Sweet Tuvia... Ripe Tuvia. Not now.
answer: Chuck? It's Tuvia! Remember? Hi!

question: Old Tuvia. Hi.
answer: You look great.

question: Yeah. Great. I'm just heading -- Uh-huh.
answer: Hi.

question: Hi.
answer: I thought it was you.

question: It's me.
answer: I'm glad to meet you because I wanted to tell you that I've seen The Gong Show and I think you are the most insidious and despicable force in entertainment today.

question: Well --
answer: How dare you subject the rest of the world to your loathsome view of humanity.

question: I don't think it's that loathsome.
answer: What is it then? To mock some poor, lonely people who just crave a little attention in their lives. To destroy them. So everybody's not brilliantly talented. They're still people. They deserve respect and compassion. I mean, who the hell are you? What the fuck have you ever done that elevates you above the pathetic masses? Oh, I forgot, you created The Dating Game. Wow, right up there with the Sistine Chapel. I guess that's what gives you the right to...

question: Who Am I? Fuck. Shit. Piss.
answer: Barris.

question: How'd you know where I was?
answer: Chuck, Chuck, Chuck, don't be an orangutan. We always know where you are. We always know what you're doing. By the by, I'd think twice before I'd attempt to get that tripe you're writing published. And there's a typo on page --

question: Look, what do you want, Oliver? I don't work for you anymore. I have things to...
answer: I'd like you to come back for one last assignment, Chuck.

question: No. Now get... Good-bye
answer: I think you might be interested when I tell you it's the mole who fingered your friends Jim Byrd and Paul Picard... and Seigfried Keeler.

question: Keeler committed suicide.
answer: Yes, of course he did. He threw himself from a twentieth floor window after he strangled himself to death with an electrical cord.

question: I'm not interested, Oliver.
answer: As long as the mole's alive, you don't have a chance in hell of remaining so. Besides, killing is in your blood, old man. You fit the profile.

question: That fucking profile again! What's the fuck is it?! What the fuck do you bastards know about me, that I don't?!
answer: Indeed. Where to begin. First, let go of me. Let's see. Well, you had a twin sister, stillborn, strangled by your umbilical cord. Your first hit, Chuck. Your mother always wanted a daughter. She blamed you for your sister's death. And, so, until your sister Phoebe was born, she raised you as a girl.

question: That's not true.
answer: Oh, and your father the dentist? Not really your father. Your biological father was a man named Edmund James Windsor. A serial killer. A fact your mother didn't know when she had an affair with him in 1930. If you want to look him up, he was also known as the Tarrytown Troll, because he had been described by witnesses as short and ugly. Windsor died in the electrical chair at Ossining in 1939. We believed your self- loathing tendencies coupled with that extra Y chromosome and whatever else you inherited from your father would serve us well.

question: You're lying.
answer: I'm trying to think what more I can tell you. I'm sure there's more. But you have me at a disadvantage here, Barris. I don't have your files in front of me.

question: Just leave me the hell alone!
answer: Your mother always loved the game shows, and you so wanted to please her. We never expected the game show business to work out for you. But that it did, turned out to be in our favor. I guess your need to be a good daughter drove you more than we anticipated.

question: Huh? What?
answer: Chuck? It's Pen. Oh, Chuck.

question: Jesus, how'd you find me? Am I listed in some guidebook or something?
answer: You sent me your last letter on hotel stationary.

question: Oh. Well, it's great to see you, Pen. You look beautiful.
answer: I don't really. But I appreciate the lie. I know how you hate lying. Boy, this place is scary looking.

question: Yeah. The human psyche.
answer: I came to take you back to California with me. It's a lonely state without you.

question: I don't know, Redhead.
answer: I can't wait forever for you to ask me to marry you, you know. Well, apparently I can. But I really don't want to. Chuck.

question: Pen.
answer: I love you so much. You don't understand. I don't even know why. You're such a schmuck.

question: You don't know the half of it.
answer: You're not gonna marry me, are you?

question: I don't know if I can.
answer: I can't believe you finally left your two- hundred-dollar-a-night cave to see me. I'm honored.

question: Y'know, I got a visit this morning from Penny. She's wanted to marry me forever. But she doesn't know who I am, what I've, what I'm capable of. And she can't ever know. So what does she really love? A lie. And I started thinking, Treesh, you are the only woman in the world who truly knows me. I know I've screwed you over in the past, and I'm really sorry. I just want you to know that you're the one I want to be with. I love you, Treesh. I hate myself for how I've lived, Treesh.
answer: Neitzsche said, "Whoever despises oneself still respects oneself as one who despises."

question: I never thought of that. Jesus, I can't even despise myself with any insight.
answer: Insane asylums are filled with people who think they're Jesus or Satan. Very few have delusions of being the guy down the block who works at an insurance company. Wonder what that means.

question: Y'know, I wanted to be a writer once. I wanted to write something that someday some lesser person would quote. But I never did. I'm the lesser person, Treesh. I never said anything meaningful that wasn't said by somebody else first. I am disposable. I disposed of people and I am disposable. You look cold.
answer: Chuck, what's gotten into you? You're actually acting like a gentleman. Well, it's late. I should get going.

question: I suppose you still won't tell me where you're staying.
answer: No. But I'll show you. Drink?

question: Sure. Bourbon.
answer: I've been thinking a lot about you lately, Chuck.

question: Yeah?
answer: I've missed you.

question: You could've fooled me.
answer: Well, I've mellowed. Look. Boston's a beautiful city. We could start over here. A normal person's life. Together. Selling insurance.

question: That sounds right.
answer: To life.

question: Hey, Redhead? Drive, Danny! Now!
answer: What's going on?

question: Pen, I have something to confess.
answer: Okay.

question: You know me as the creator of The Dating Game, The Newlywed Game, The Family Game, The Game Game, How's Your Mother-in-law, Dream Girl of 1968...
answer: Operation Entertainment.

question: Yeah, Operation Entertainment. The Rah- Rah Show, Gong Show, The Dollar-Ninety- Eight Beauty Show, The Ra-Rah Show...
answer: You said that already.
